resources.string: Color Picker:\n Primary colors are any of a group of colors from which all other colors can be obtained by mixing. In real world applications the most common colors chosen are red, blue, and yellow. When it come to representing colors digitally, the RGB24 (red, green, blue) model is most popular. This App lets you play around with different model and lets you generate your own colors.

How to Use:
 RGB and HSV:
 Move the slider to select a value from 0-255 (0-360 for hue, 0-100 for saturation and value). Do this for each slider to get your desired color.
 Hex:
 Enter a valid hexadecimal color value (i.e. 0-9, A-F) and hit enter on your keyboard.
 When a desired color is found you can copy the hexadecimal value to your clipboard via the "Save" option. This will also save the color in your "Saved Colors" menu.
 Saved Colors:
 To resave the hexadecimal value to your clipboard, tap the desired color from your list of colors. If you wish to delete a color from your Saved Colors menu, press and hold.
(RGB)\n This scheme restricts the number of available values to 8 bits in three color channels with values of 0–255. This means that any given color can be one of 16,777,216 possible colors.

(HSV)\n Hue, Saturation, Value is an alternative representations of the RGB color model. It more closely aligns with the way human vision perceives color-making attributes. The HSV representation models the way paints of different colors mix together, with the saturation dimension resembling various shades of brightly colored paint, and the value dimension resembling the mixture of those paints with varying amounts of black or white paint.

(CMYK)\n Cyan, Magenta, Yellow, Black is a subtractive color model, used in color printing. The CMYK model works by partially or entirely masking colors on a lighter, usually white, background. The ink reduces the light that would otherwise be reflected.

(Hex)\n A hex triplet is a six-digit, three-byte hexadecimal number used to represent colors in computing applications. The bytes represent the red, green and blue components of the color. One byte represents a number in the range 00 to FF (in hexadecimal notation), or 0 to 255 in decimal notation.
